think_procedure: To determine whether 'min_wal_size' is a special knob in PostgreSQL, I first need to understand what the knob does and its range of valid values. 'min_wal_size' sets the minimum size of WAL files that PostgreSQL will maintain at any time to ensure a smooth operation of the database. The value for 'min_wal_size' is specified in megabytes and typically has a default value and a range within which it can be adjusted. After reviewing PostgreSQL documentation and resources, it appears that 'min_wal_size' does not have any documented special values such as -1 or 0 that would change its behavior fundamentally (e.g., disabling WAL or changing how WAL files are managed in a non-linear or non-standard way). Instead, setting it too low or too high simply affects performance or disk usage without altering the fundamental behavior of the WAL mechanism.
